NASA/JPL }} }} {{Infobox spaceflight/IP | type = orbiter | object = Jupiter | orbits = 49{{Cite press release |title=All Systems Go for NASA's Mission to Jupiter Moon Europa |date=June 17, 2015 |publisher=NASA |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/all-systems-go-for-nasas-mission-to-jupiter-moon-europa |access-date=May 29, 2019 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210311172634/http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/all-systems-go-for-nasas-mission-to-jupiter-moon-europa/ |archive-date=March 11, 2021}} {{Source-attribution}} | arrival_date = April 11, 2030 (first closest approach to Europa){{cite web | url=https://eyes.nasa.gov/apps/solar-system/#/sc_europa_clipper/distance?to=europa&time=2030-04-11T10:47:03.003+00:00&rate=0 | title=Eyes on the Solar System - NASA/JPL }} }} | instruments_list = {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments |acronym1 = [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding|PIMS]] | name1 = Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding |acronym2 = [[Europa Clipper Magnetometer|ECM]] | name2 = Europa Clipper Magnetometer |acronym3 = [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa|MISE]] | name3 = Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa |acronym4 = [[Europa Imaging System|EIS]] | name4 = Europa Imaging System |acronym5 = [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface|REASON]] | name5 = Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface |acronym6 = [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System|E-THEMIS]] | name6 = Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System |acronym7 = [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration|MASPEX]] | name7 = MAss SPectrometer for Planetary EXploration |acronym8 = [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph|Europa-UVS]] | name8 = Europa-Ultraviolet Spectrograph |acronym9 = [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUDA]] | name9 = SUrface Dust Analyzer{{Cite web |last=Thompson |first=Jay R. |year=2022 |title=Instruments |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/mission/science-instruments/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210524211103/https://europa.nasa.gov/mission/science-instruments/ |archive-date=May 24, 2021 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |website=Europa Clipper |publisher=NASA}}{{Source-attribution}} }} | insignia = Europa Clipper patch.png | insignia_caption = Europa Clipper mission patch | programme = '''[[Large Strategic Science Missions]]'''
''Planetary Science Division'' | previous_mission = [[Mars 2020]] | next_mission = [[NASA-ESA Mars Sample Return|Mars Sample Return]] | programme2 = '''[[Planetary Missions Program Office#Solar System Exploration|Solar System Exploration program]]''' | previous_mission2 = [[Double Asteroid Redirection Test|DART]] | next_mission2 = [[Uranus Orbiter and Probe]] }} '''Europa Clipper''' (previously known as '''Europa Multiple Flyby Mission''') is a [[space probe]] developed by [[NASA]] to study [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], a [[Galilean moon]] of [[Jupiter]]. It was launched on October 14, 2024.{{Cite web |date=October 14, 2024 |title=NASA's Europa Clipper launches aboard SpaceX rocket, bound for Jupiter's icy ocean moon |url=https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2024-10-14/nasa-jupiter-probe-launches-aboard-spacex-rocket |access-date=October 14, 2024 |website=Los Angeles Times}} The spacecraft will use [[gravity assist]]s from Mars on March 1, 2025, and Earth on December 3, 2026, before arriving at Europa in April 2030.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=February 10, 2021 |title=NASA to use commercial launch vehicle for Europa Clipper |url=https://spacenews.com/nasa-to-use-commercial-launch-vehicle-for-europa-clipper/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20210216064656/https://spacenews.com/nasa%2Dto%2Duse%2Dcommercial%2Dlaunch%2Dvehicle%2Dfor%2Deuropa%2Dclipper/ |archive-date=February 16, 2021 |access-date=February 10, 2021 |publisher=SpaceNews}} The spacecraft will then perform a series of [[Flyby (spaceflight)|flybys]] of Europa while in orbit around Jupiter.{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stuart |title='It's like finding needles in a haystack': the mission to discover if Jupiter's moons support life |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/mar/05/could-jupiters-icy-moons-support-life |date=March 5, 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=March 7, 2023 |archive-date=March 7, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230307013722/https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/mar/05/could-jupiters-icy-moons-support-life |url-status=live }}{{Cite web |last1=King |first1=Lucinda |last2=Conversation |first2=The |title=If life exists on Jupiter's moon Europa, scientists might soon be able to detect it |url=https://phys.org/news/2024-04-life-jupiter-moon-europa-scientists.html |access-date=April 8, 2024 |website=phys.org |language=en |archive-date=April 8, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240408032324/https://phys.org/news/2024-04-life-jupiter-moon-europa-scientists.html |url-status=live }} Europa Clipper is designed to follow up on evidence for a subsurface ocean underneath Europa's ice [[Crust (geology)|crust]], found using the [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]] spacecraft which orbited Jupiter from 1995 to 2003. Plans to send a spacecraft to Europa were initially conceived with projects such as [[Europa Orbiter]] and [[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]], in which a spacecraft would be inserted into orbit around Europa. However, due to the adverse effects of [[radiation]] from the [[magnetosphere of Jupiter]] in Europa orbit, it was decided that it would be safer to insert a spacecraft into an [[Elliptic orbit|elliptical orbit]] around Jupiter and make 49 close flybys of the moon instead.{{Cite web |title=Europa Clipper - NASA Science |url=https://science.nasa.gov/mission/europa-clipper/ |access-date=2024-11-19 |website=science.nasa.gov |language=en-US}} The Europa Clipper spacecraft is larger than any other used for previous NASA planetary missions.{{Cite web |date=April 19, 2024 |title=How our vision of Europa's habitability is changing |url=https://www.sciencenews.org/article/vision-europa-habitability-jupiter-moon |access-date=April 24, 2024 |language=en-US |archive-date=April 24, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240424173703/https://www.sciencenews.org/article/vision-europa-habitability-jupiter-moon |url-status=live }} The spacecraft will analyze the presence of an [[Europa (moon)#Internal structure|induced magnetic field around Europa]], and attempt to detect plumes of water [[ejecta]] from a subsurface ocean; in addition to various other tests.{{Cite web |title=In Depth |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/in-depth/ |access-date=2024-12-09 |website=NASA's Europa Clipper |language=en}} The mission's name is a reference to the lightweight and fast [[Clipper|clipper ships]] of the 19th century that routinely plied trade routes, since the spacecraft will pass by Europa at a rapid cadence, as frequently as every two weeks. The mission patch, which features a depiction of a sail ship, references the moniker.{{Cite web |last=Dyches |first=Preston |date=March 9, 2017 |title=NASA Mission Named 'Europa Clipper' |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6772 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202164049/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6772 |archive-date=December 2, 2020 |access-date=October 28, 2017 |publisher=JPL (NASA)}} {{Source-attribution}} Europa Clipper complements the [[European Space Agency|ESA]]'s [[Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer]], launched in 2023, which will attempt to fly past Europa twice and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] multiple times before moving into orbit around [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]]. == History == === Early proposals and Galileo discoveries === In 1997, a [[Europa Orbiter]] mission was proposed by a team for NASA's [[Discovery Program]]{{Cite conference |last1=Edwards |first1=Bradley C. |last2=Chyba |first2=Christopher F. |last3=Abshire |first3=James B. |last4=Burns |first4=Joseph A. |last5=Geissler |first5=Paul |last6=Konopliv |first6=Alex S. |last7=Malin |first7=Michael C. |last8=Ostro |first8=Steven J. |last9=Rhodes |first9=Charley |date=July 11, 1997 |title=The Europa Ocean Discovery mission |conference=Proc. SPIE 3111, Instruments, Methods, and Missions for the Investigation of Extraterrestrial Microorganisms |doi=10.1117/12.278778 |first10=Chuck |last10=Rudiger |first11=Xuan-Min |last11=Shao |first12=David E. |last12=Smith |first13=Steven W. |last13=Squyres |first14=Peter C. |last14=Thomas |first15=Chauncey W. |last15=Uphoff |first16=Gerald D. |last16=Walberg |first17=Charles L. |last17=Werner |first18=Charles F. |last18=Yoder |first19=Maria T. |last19=Zuber}} but was not selected. NASA's JPL announced one month after the selection of Discovery proposals that a NASA Europa orbiter mission would be conducted. JPL then invited the Discovery proposal team to be the Mission Review Committee (MRC).{{citation needed|date=September 2020}} At the same time as the proposal of the Discovery-class Europa Orbiter, the robotic [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]] spacecraft was already orbiting Jupiter. From December 8, 1995, to December 7, 1997, Galileo conducted the primary mission after entering the orbit of Jupiter. On that final date, the Galileo orbiter commenced an extended mission known as the Galileo Europa Mission (GEM), which ran until December 31, 1999. This was a low-cost mission extension with a budget of only US$30 million. The smaller team of about 40–50 people (compared with the primary mission's 200-person team from 1995 to 1997) did not have the resources to deal with problems, but when they arose, it was able to temporarily recall former team members (called "tiger teams") for intensive efforts to solve them. The spacecraft made several flybys of Europa (8), [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] (4) and [[Io (moon)|Io]] (2). On each flyby of the three moons it encountered, the spacecraft collected only two days' worth of data instead of the seven it had collected during the primary mission. During GEM's eight flybys of Europa, it ranged from {{Convert abbreviated|196|to|3582|km}}, in two years.{{Cite book |last=Meltzer |first=Michael |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf |title=Mission to Jupiter: A History of the Galileo Project |publisher=NASA |year=2007 |series=The NASA History Series |oclc=124150579 |id=SP-4231 |access-date=December 4, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201128052208/https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf |archive-date=November 28, 2020 |url-status=live}} {{Source-attribution}} Europa has been identified as one of the locations in the [[Solar System]] that could possibly harbor microbial [[extraterrestrial life]].{{Cite news |last=Dreier |first=Casey |date=December 12, 2013 |title=Europa: No Longer a 'Should', But a 'Must' |publisher=The Planetary Society |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/1212-europa-no-longer-a-should-but-a-must.html |url-status=live |access-date=December 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190908093842/http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/1212-europa-no-longer-a-should-but-a-must.html |archive-date=September 8, 2019}}{{Cite web |last1=Schulze-Makuch |first1=Dirk |last2=Irwin |first2=Louis N. |year=2001 |title=Alternative Energy Sources Could Support Life on Europa |url=http://www.geo.utep.edu/pub/dirksm/geobiowater/pdf/EOS27March2001.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060703033956/http://www.geo.utep.edu/pub/dirksm/geobiowater/pdf/EOS27March2001.pdf |archive-date=July 3, 2006 |website=Departments of Geological and Biological Sciences |publisher=University of Texas at El Paso}}{{Cite news |last=Zabarenko |first=Deborah |date=March 7, 2011 |title=Lean U.S. missions to Mars, Jupiter moon recommended |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-usa-future-idUSTRE7266XJ20110308 |url-status=live |access-date=July 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200907012354/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-usa-future-idUSTRE7266XJ20110308 |archive-date=September 7, 2020}} Immediately following the Galileo spacecraft's discoveries and the independent Discovery program proposal for a Europa orbiter, JPL conducted preliminary mission studies that envisioned a capable spacecraft such as the [[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]] (a US$16 billion mission concept),{{Cite web |year=2005 |title=Project Prometheus final report |page =178 |url=http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/38185/1/05-3441.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304221142/http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/38185/1/05-3441.pdf |archive-date=March 4, 2016 |access-date=January 20, 2015}} {{Source-attribution}} the [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] (a US$4.3 billion concept), another orbiter (US$2 billion concept), and a multi-flyby spacecraft: Europa Clipper. A mission to Europa was recommended by the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] in 2013. The approximate cost estimate rose from US$2 billion in 2013 to US$4.25 billion in 2020.{{cite news|url=https://spacenews.com/europa-clipper-passes-key-review/|title=Europa Clipper passes key review|author=Jeff Foust|date=August 22, 2019|publisher=[[Space News]]|access-date=July 4, 2023|archive-date=February 27, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230227101309/https://spacenews.com/europa-clipper-passes-key-review/|url-status=live}}[https://www.space.com/nasa-europa-mission-alien-life.html NASA Europa Mission Could Potentially Spot Signs of Alien Life] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210126130808/https://www.space.com/nasa-europa-mission-alien-life.html |date=January 26, 2021 }}, Mike Wall, Space.com, October 26, 2019 The mission is a joint project between the [[Johns Hopkins University]]'s [[Applied Physics Laboratory]] (APL), and the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL).{{Cite conference |last1=Pappalardo |first1=Robert |last2=Cooke |first2=Brian |last3=Goldstein |first3=Barry |last4=Prockter |first4=Louise |last5=Senske |first5=Dave |last6=Magner |first6=Tom |date=July 2013 |title=OPAG Update |publisher=Lunar and Planetary Institute |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210125054349/https://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/jul2013/presentations/Clipper_Summary.pdf |archive-date=January 25, 2021 |access-date=December 13, 2013 |contribution=The Europa Clipper |contribution-url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/jul2013/presentations/Clipper_Summary.pdf |url-status=live}} === Funding put forward === In March 2013, US$75 million was authorized to expand on the formulation of mission activities, mature the proposed science goals, and fund preliminary instrument development,{{Cite news |date=March 29, 2013 |title=Destination: Europa |publisher=Europa SETI |url=http://europa.seti.org/one-small-step-for-a-mission/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823091007/http://europa.seti.org/one-small-step-for-a-mission/ |archive-date=August 23, 2014}} as suggested in 2011 by the [[Planetary Science Decadal Survey]].{{Cite news |last=Leone |first=Dan |date=July 22, 2013 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Concept Progresses on the Back Burner |publisher=SpaceNews |url=http://spacenews.com/36388nasas-europa-mission-concept-progresses-on-the-back-burner/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20160222162720/http://spacenews.com/36388nasas-europa-mission-concept-progresses-on-the-back-burner/ |archive-date=February 22, 2016}} In May 2014, a House bill substantially increased the Europa Clipper (referred to as ''Europa Multiple Flyby Mission'') funding budget for the 2014 fiscal year from US$15 million{{Cite news |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=March 5, 2014 |title=NASA Eyes Ambitious Mission to Jupiter's Icy Moon Europa by 2025 |publisher=Space.com |url=http://www.space.com/24926-nasa-europa-mission-2015-budget.html |url-status=live |access-date=April 15, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180908194715/https://www.space.com/24926-nasa-europa-mission-2015-budget.html |archive-date=September 8, 2018}}{{Cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=March 14, 2014 |title=Economics, water plumes to drive Europa mission study |publisher=Spaceflight Now |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1403/14europa/ |url-status=live |access-date=April 15, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416182657/http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1403/14europa/ |archive-date=April 16, 2014}} to US$100 million to be applied to pre-formulation work.{{Cite news |last=Zezima |first=Katie |date=May 8, 2014 |title=House gives NASA more money to explore planets |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/05/08/house-gives-nasa-more-money-to-explore-planets/ |url-status=live |access-date=May 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150513200006/http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/05/08/house-gives-nasa-more-money-to-explore-planets/ |archive-date=May 13, 2015}}{{Cite news |last=Morin |first=Monte |date=May 8, 2014 |title=US$17.9-billion funding plan for NASA would boost planetary science |work=Los Angeles Times |url=http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-nasa-house-appropriations-committee-20140507-story.html |url-status=live |access-date=May 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112025606/https://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-nasa-house-appropriations-committee-20140507-story.html |archive-date=November 12, 2020}} Following the [[United States elections, 2014|2014 election cycle]], bipartisan support was pledged to continue funding for the ''Europa Multiple Flyby Mission'' project.{{Cite web |last=Nola Taylor Redd |date=November 5, 2014 |title=To Europa! Mission to Jupiter's Moon Gains Support in Congress |url=http://www.space.com/27660-jupiter-moon-europa-exploration-congress.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201127084926/https://www.space.com/27660-jupiter-moon-europa-exploration-congress.html |archive-date=November 27, 2020 |access-date=November 6, 2014 |publisher=Space.com}}{{Cite web |last=Dreier |first=Casey |date=February 3, 2015 |title=It's Official: We're On the Way to Europa |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2015/0202-its-official-we-are-on-the-way-to-europa-fy2016.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200111202738/https://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2015/0202-its-official-we-are-on-the-way-to-europa-fy2016.html |archive-date=January 11, 2020 |access-date=February 8, 2015 |publisher=The Planetary Society}} The executive branch also granted US$30 million for preliminary studies.{{Cite web |last=Kane |first=Van |date=February 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201108093519/http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2015/02/2016-budget-great-policy-document-and.html |archive-date=November 8, 2020 |access-date=February 8, 2015 |publisher=Future Planetary Exploration}}{{Cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |date=March 10, 2015 |title=Europa Multiple Flyby Mission concept team aims for launch in 2022 |publisher=Spaceflight Now |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/03/10/europa-clipper-concept-team-aims-for-launch-in-2022/ |url-status=live |access-date=April 9, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808162453/https://spaceflightnow.com/2015/03/10/europa-clipper-concept-team-aims-for-launch-in-2022/ |archive-date=August 8, 2016}} === Formulation === In Europa Clipper was finally launched on October 14, 2024. ===End of mission planning=== The probe is scheduled to be crashed into Jupiter, [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]], or Callisto, to protect it from crashing into Europa. In June 2022, lead project scientist Robert Pappalardo revealed that mission planners for Europa Clipper were considering disposing of the probe by crashing it into the surface of Ganymede in case an extended mission was not approved early in the main science phase. He noted that an impact would help the ESA's [[Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer|JUICE]] mission collect more information about Ganymede's surface chemistry.{{cite web | title=14 OPAG June 2022 Day 2 Bob bibcode=2024SSRv..220...40P }} == Objectives == [[File:Photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa]] [[File:EuropaClipper.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The concept to achieve global-regional coverage of Europa during successive flybys]] The goals of Europa Clipper are to explore Europa, investigate its [[Habitability of natural satellites|habitability]] and aid in the selection of a landing site for the proposed [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{Cite journal |last1=Pappalardo |first1=Robert life: [[Water|liquid water]], [[chemistry]], and energy.{{Cite conference |last1=Bayer |first1=Todd |last2=Buffington |first2=Brent |last3=Castet |first3=Jean-Francois |last4=Jackson |first4=Maddalena |last5=Lee |first5=Gene |last6=Lewis |first6=Kari |last7=Kastner |first7=Jason |last8=Schimmels |first8=Kathy |last9=Kirby |first9=Karen |date=March 4, 2017 |title=2017 IEEE Aerospace Conference Specifically, the objectives are to study: * Ice shell and ocean: Confirm the existence and characterize the nature of water within or beneath the ice, and study processes of surface-ice-ocean exchange. * Composition: Distribution and chemistry of key compounds and the links to ocean composition. * Geology: Characteristics and formation of surface features, including sites of recent or current activity. The spacecraft carries [[Europa Clipper#Scientific equipment|scientific instruments]] which will be used to analyze the potential presence of geothermal activity and the Moon's [[Europa (moon)#Internal structure|induced magnetic field]]; which in turn will provide an indication to the presence of saline rich subsurface ocean(s). === Strategy === [[File:Europa_Clipper_Radiation.png|thumb|upright=1.1|left|A wide orbit of Jupiter with several flybys of Europa will minimize radiation exposure and increase data transfer speed.]] Because Europa lies well within the [[Magnetosphere of Jupiter|harsh radiation fields]] surrounding Jupiter, even a radiation-hardened spacecraft in near orbit would be functional for just a few months.{{Cite news |last=Kane |first=Van |date=August 26, 2014 |title=Europa: How Less Can Be More |publisher=Planetary Society |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html |url-status=live |access-date=August 29, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191117080735/https://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html |archive-date=November 17, 2019}} Most instruments can gather data far faster than the communications system can transmit it to Earth due to the limited number of antennas available on Earth to receive the scientific data. Therefore, another key limiting factor on science for a Europa orbiter is the time available to return data to Earth. In contrast, the amount of time during which the instruments can make close-up observations is less important. Studies by scientists from the Jet Propulsion Laboratory show that by performing several flybys with many months to return data, the Europa Clipper concept will enable a US$2 billion mission to conduct the most crucial measurements of the canceled US$4.3 billion [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] concept. Between each of the flybys, the spacecraft will have seven to ten days to transmit data stored during each brief encounter. That will let the spacecraft have up to a year of time to transmit its data compared to just 30 days for an orbiter. The result will be almost three times as much data returned to Earth, while reducing exposure to radiation. Europa Clipper will not orbit Europa, but will instead orbit [[Jupiter]] and conduct 44 [[List of planetary flybys|flyby]]s of Europa, each at altitudes ranging from 25 km to 2,700 km (16 mi to 1,678 mi) during its 3.5-year mission.{{Cite journal |last1=Phillips |first1=Cynthia B. |author-link=Cynthia B. Phillips |last2=Pappalardo |first2=Robert T. |date=May 20, 2014 |title=Europa Clipper Mission Concept |journal=Eos Transactions |publisher=Eos Transactions American Geophysical Union |volume=95 |issue=20 |pages=165–167 |bibcode=2014EOSTr..95..165P |doi=10.1002/2014EO200002 |doi-access=free}}{{Cite web |title=Europa Clipper |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210323162742/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper |archive-date=March 23, 2021 |access-date=January 2, 2019 |publisher=NASA (JPL)}} {{Source-attribution}} A key feature of the mission concept is that Europa Clipper would use [[gravity assist]]s from Europa, Ganymede and Callisto to change its trajectory, allowing the spacecraft to return to a different close approach point with each flyby. Each flyby would cover a different sector of Europa to achieve a medium-quality global topographic survey, including ice thickness.{{Cite news |last=Kane |first=Van |date=May 26, 2013 |title=Europa Clipper Update |publisher=Future Planetary Exploration |url=http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html |url-status=live |access-date=December 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210204070619/http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html |archive-date=February 4, 2021}} Europa Clipper could conceivably fly by at low altitude through the plumes of water vapor erupting from the moon's ice crust, thus sampling its subsurface ocean without having to land on the surface and drill through the ice. The spacecraft is expected to receive a total ionizing dose of {{convert|2.8|Mrad|kGy}} during the mission. Shielding from Jupiter's harsh radiation belt will be provided by a radiation vault with {{convert|0.3|in|mm}} thick aluminum alloy walls, which enclose the spacecraft electronics.{{Cite web |title=Meet Europa Clipper |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/meet-europa-clipper/ |access-date=November 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA |archive-date=November 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221113172234/https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/meet-europa-clipper/ |url-status=live }} To maximize the effectiveness of this shielding, the electronics are also nested in the core of the spacecraft for additional radiation protection. == Design and construction == [[File:Europa-Clipper-Diagram.png|thumb|upright=2.0|Spacecraft diagram]] This mission is a flight of NASA's [[Planetary Science Division]], designated a [[Large strategic science missions|Large Strategic Science Mission]], and funded under the [[Planetary Missions Program Office]]'s |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731023935/https://www.aip.org/fyi/2017/balance-nasa-planetary-science-missions-explored-hearing |archive-date=July 31, 2020 |access-date=May 29, 2019 |publisher=American Institute of Physics}}{{Cite web |title=Solar System Exploration Missions List |url=https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180327141053/https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration |archive-date=March 27, 2018 |access-date=March 27, 2018 |website=Planetary Missions Program Office (PMPO) |publisher=NASA}} {{Source-attribution}} It is also supported by the new [[Ocean Worlds Exploration Program]]. The [[spacecraft bus]] is a 5-meter-long combination of a 150-cm-wide aluminum cylindrical propulsion module and a rectangular box. The electronic components are protected from the intense radiation by a 150-kilogram [[titanium]], [[zinc]] and aluminum shielded vault in the box. The spacecraft payload and trajectory are subject to change as the mission design matures.{{Cite conference |last1=Amato |first1=Michael J. |last2=Spidaliere |first2=P. |last3=Mahaffy |first3=P. |year=2016 |title=Biosignature Explorer for Europa (BEE) Probe – The Concept for Directly Searching for Life Evidence on Europa at Lower Cost and Risk |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf |conference=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122232905/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf |archive-date=January 22, 2017 |access-date=September 28, 2016 |url-status=live}}{{Update inline|date=October 2024}} === Power === Both [[radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (RTG) and [[photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] power sources were assessed to power the orbiter.A. Eremenko ''et al.'', "Europa Clipper spacecraft configuration evolution", ''2014 IEEE Aerospace Conference'', pp. 1–13, Big Sky, MT, March 1–8, 2014 Although solar power is only 4% as intense at Jupiter as it is in Earth's orbit, powering a Jupiter orbital spacecraft by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]] was demonstrated by the [[Juno (spacecraft)|Juno mission]]. The alternative to solar panels was a [[multi-mission radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (MMRTG), fueled with [[plutonium-238]]. The power source has already been demonstrated in the [[Mars Science Laboratory]] (MSL) mission. Five units were available, with one reserved for the [[Mars 2020 rover mission]] and another as backup. In September 2013, it was decided that the solar array was the less expensive option to power the spacecraft, and on October 3, 2014, it was announced that solar panels were chosen to power Europa Clipper. The mission's designers determined that solar power was both cheaper than plutonium and practical to use on the spacecraft. Despite the increased weight of solar panels compared to plutonium-powered generators, the vehicle's mass had been projected to still be within acceptable launch limits.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=October 8, 2014 |title=Europa Clipper Opts for Solar Power over Nuclear |url=http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20150209194443/http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/ |archive-date=February 9, 2015 |access-date=February 8, 2015 |publisher=SpaceNews}} Each panel has a surface area of {{Convert abbreviated|18|sqm}} and produces 150 watts continuously when pointed towards the Sun while orbiting Jupiter.{{Cite news |last=Dreier |first=Casey |date=September 5, 2013 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Concept Rejects ASRGs – May Use Solar Panels at Jupiter Instead |publisher=The Planetary Society |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html |url-status=live |access-date=December 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710011405/http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html |archive-date=July 10, 2018}} While in Europa's shadow, batteries will enable the spacecraft to continue gathering data. However, [[ionizing radiation]] can damage solar panels. The Europa Clipper{{'s}} orbit will pass through Jupiter's intense magnetosphere, which is expected to gradually degrade the solar panels as the mission progresses. The solar panels were provided by [[Airbus Defence and Space]], Netherlands.{{Cite magazine |date=March 2018 |title=Spacecraft Highlights |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf |url-status=live |magazine=The Sextant – Europa Clipper Newsletter |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |volume=2 |issue=1 |page=3 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134354/https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf |archive-date=October 10, 2022 |access-date=September 20, 2018}} {{Source-attribution}} === Propulsion === The propulsion subsystem was built by NASA's [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] in [[Greenbelt, Maryland]]. It is part of the Propulsion Module,{{cite press release | last=Rehm|first=Jeremy|date=7 July 2022 | title=Johns Hopkins APL Delivers Propulsion Module for NASA Mission to Europa | url=https://www.jhuapl.edu/news/news-releases/220607-johns-hopkins-apl-delivers-nasa-europa-clipper-propulsion-module}} delivered by [[Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory]] in [[Laurel, Maryland]]. It is {{Convert|10|ft|4=0|order=flip}} tall, {{Convert|5|ft|order=flip}} in diameter and comprises about two-thirds of the spacecraft's main body. The propulsion subsystem carries nearly {{Convert|6000|lb|order=flip}} of [[monomethyl hydrazine]] and [[dinitrogen tetroxide]] propellant, 50% to 60% of which will be used for the 6 to 8-hour Jupiter orbit insertion burn. The spacecraft has a total of 24 rocket engines rated at 27.5 N (6.2 lbf) thrust for attitude control and propulsion. === Communication === [[File:PIA22773 Europa Clipper Antenna Prototype.jpg|thumb|Prototype of the high-gain antenna during testing]] {{expand section|date=October 2024}} The probe contains multiple antennas, including the high-gain antenna, which has a 3.1-meter (10-foot) diameter. The high-gain antenna operates on [[X-band]] frequencies of 7.2 and 8.4 gigahertz, and a [[Ka-band]] frequency of 32 gigahertz (12 times that of a typical cell phone).The antennas will be used to research gravity and radio science, allowing researchers to learn more about Europa's gravityhttps://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/meet-europa-clipper/ It was designed and constructed by a team led by Matt Bray at the [[Applied Physics Laboratory|Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory]], before being tested at [[Langley Research Center]] and [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] in the spring and summer of 2022.{{cite web | title=Europa Clipper High-Gain Antenna Undergoes Precision Testing at NASA Langley | website=NASA | date=August 4, 2022 | url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers-and-facilities/langley/europa-clipper-high-gain-antenna-undergoes-precision-testing-at-nasa-langley/ | access-date=October 22, 2024}} === Scientific equipment === The Europa Clipper mission is equipped with nine scientific instruments.{{Cite journal |last1=Becker |first1=T. T. |date=August 2024 |title=Exploring the Composition of Europa with the Upcoming Europa Clipper Mission |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11214-024-01069-y |journal=Space Science Reviews |volume=220 |issue=5 |pages=49 |bibcode=2024SSRv..220...49B |doi=10.1007/s11214-024-01069-y |issn=1572-9672 |display-authors=15 |language=en|doi-access=free }} The nine science instruments for the orbiter, announced in May 2015, have a planned total mass of {{Convert abbreviated|82|kg}}.{{Update inline|date=October 2024}}{{Cite news |date=May 26, 2015 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Begins with Selection of Science Instruments |publisher=NASA (JPL) |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598 |url-status=live |access-date=May 27, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926192203/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598 |archive-date=September 26, 2020}} {{Source-attribution}} ==== Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System (E-THEMIS) ==== The [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System]] will provide high spatial resolution as well as multi-spectral imaging of the surface of Europa in the [[Infrared|mid]] to [[far infrared]] bands to help detect heat which would suggest geologically active sites and areas, such as potential vents erupting plumes of water into space.{{Cite web |title=OPAG Meeting |url=https://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/meetings/aug2015/presentations/day-1/8_e_christensen.pdf |website=lpi.usra.edu}} The [[principal investigator]] is [[Philip Christensen]] of [[Arizona State University]]. This instrument is derived from the [[Thermal Emission Imaging System]] (THEMIS) on the [[2001 Mars Odyssey]] orbiter, also developed by Philip Christensen.{{Cite web |date=April 25, 2019 |title=E-THEMIS {{!}} Christensen Research Group |url=http://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134358/https://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/ |archive-date=October 10, 2022 |access-date=May 14, 2021 |website=Christensen Research Group |publisher=[[Arizona State University]]}} ==== Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa (MISE) ==== [[File:Europa Clipper’s Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|The [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa]] instrument]] The Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa is an imaging [[Infrared spectroscopy|near infrared spectrometer]] to probe the surface composition of Europa, identifying and mapping the distributions of [[organic compound|organics]] (including [[amino acid]]s and [[tholin]]s[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W MISE: A Search for Organics on Europa] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116052227/http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W |date=November 16, 2018 }}, Whalen, Kelly; Lunine, Jonathan I.; [[Diana Blaney|Blaney, Diana L.]]; ''American Astronomical Society'', AAS Meeting No. 229, id.138.04, January 2017{{Cite news |date=May 27, 2015 |title=Europa Mission to Probe Magnetic Field and Chemistry |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602 |url-status=live |access-date=October 23, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202163713/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602 |archive-date=December 2, 2020}} {{Source-attribution}}), salts, acid hydrates, water ice phases, and other materials.{{Cite news |last=Blaney |first=Diana L.|author-link=Diana Blaney |year=2010 |title=Europa Composition Using Visible to Short Wavelength Infrared Spectroscopy |work=JPL |publisher=American Astronomical Society, DPS meeting No. 42, #26.04; Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society, Vol. 42, p. 1025}} The principal investigator is [[Diana Blaney]] of Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the instrument was built in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL). ==== Europa Imaging System (EIS) ==== The [[Europa Imaging System]] consists of [[visible spectrum]] cameras to map Europa's surface and study smaller areas in high resolution, as low as {{Convert abbreviated|0.5|m|in}} per pixel. It consists of two cameras, both of which use 2048x4096 pixel [[CMOS Sensor|CMOS detectors]]:{{Cite web |last1=Turtle |first1=Elizabeth |author-link=Elizabeth Turtle |last2=Mcewen |first2=Alfred |author-link2=Alfred McEwen |last3=Collins |first3=G. |last4=Fletcher |first4=L. |last5=Hansen |first5=C. |last6=Hayes |first6=A. |last7=Hurford |first7=T. |last8=Kirk |first8=R. |last9=Mlinar |first9=A.C. |title=THE EUROPA IMAGING SYSTEM (EIS): HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGING AND TOPOGRAPHY TO INVESTIGATE EUROPA'S GEOLOGY, ICE SHELL, AND POTENTIAL FOR CURRENT ACTIVITY. |url=https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305231100/https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf |archive-date=March 5, 2021 |access-date=May 14, 2021 |publisher=Universities Space Research Association}}{{Cite web |title=Europa Clipper Instrument Summaries |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/internal_resources/379/ScienceInstruments_031422_Public.pdf}} * The '''Wide-angle Camera (WAC)''' has a field of view of 48° by 24° and a resolution of {{Convert abbreviated|11|m}} from a {{Convert abbreviated|50|km|mi}} altitude. Optically the WAC uses 8 lens refractive optics with an 8 mm [[aperture]] and a 46 mm [[focal length]] which give it a [[f-number]] of f/5.75. The WAC will obtain stereo imagery swaths throughout the mission. * The '''Narrow-angle Camera (NAC)''' has a 2.3° by 1.2° field of view, giving it a resolution of {{Convert abbreviated|0.5|m|in}} per pixel from a {{Convert abbreviated|50|km}} altitude. Optically the NAC uses a [[Ritchey–Chrétien telescope|Ritchey Chrétien]] [[Cassegrain reflector|Cassegrain]] telescope with a 152 mm aperture and a 1000 mm focal length which give it a f-number of f/6.58. The NAC is mounted on a 2-axis gimbal, allowing it to point at specific targets regardless of the main spacecraft's orientation. This will allow for mapping of >95% of Europa's surface at a resolution of ≤{{Convert abbreviated|50|m|ft}} per pixel. For reference, only around 14% of Europa's surface has previously been mapped at a resolution of ≤{{Convert abbreviated|500|m|ft}} per pixel. The principal investigator is [[Elizabeth Turtle]] of the Applied Physics Laboratory. ==== Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph (Europa-UVS) ==== The [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph]] instrument will be able to detect small erupting plumes, and will provide valuable data about the composition and dynamics of the moon's [[exosphere]].{{Cite web |title=The Ultraviolet Spectrograph on the Europa Mission (Europa-UVS) |url=https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2015AGUFM.P13E..02R/abstract |website=ui.adsabs.harvard.edu}} The principal investigator is Kurt Retherford of [[Southwest Research Institute]]. Retherford was previously a member of the group that discovered plumes erupting from Europa while using the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] in the [[Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy|UV spectrum]].{{Cite journal |last=Roth |first=Lorenz |year=2014 |title=Transient Water Vapor at Europa's South Pole |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=343 |issue=171 |pages=171–174 |bibcode=2014Sci...343..171R |doi=10.1126/science.1247051 |issn=1095-9203 |pmid=24336567 |s2cid=27428538}} ==== Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface (REASON) ==== The [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface]] (REASON){{Cite news |date=June 1, 2015 |title=Radar Techniques Used in Antarctica Will Scour Europa for Life-Supporting Environments |publisher=University of Texas Austin |url=http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html |url-status=live |access-date=June 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20151115171717/http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html |archive-date=November 15, 2015}}{{Cite journal |last1=Grima |first1=Cyril |last2=Schroeder |first2=Dustin |last3=Blakenship |first3=Donald D. |last4=Young |first4=Duncan A. |date=November 15, 2014 |title=Planetary landing-zone reconnaissance using ice-penetrating radar data: Concept validation in Antarctica |journal=Planetary and Space Science |volume=103 |pages=191–204 |bibcode=2014P&SS..103..191G |doi=10.1016/j.pss.2014.07.018 |doi-access=free}} is a dual-frequency [[Radioglaciology|ice penetrating radar]] (9 and 60 MHz) instrument that is designed to sound Europa's ice crust from the near-surface to the ocean, revealing the hidden structure of Europa's ice shell and potential water pockets within. REASON will probe the [[exosphere]], surface and near-surface and the full depth of the ice shell to the ice-ocean interface up to 30 km. The principal investigator is Donald Blankenship of the [[University of Texas at Austin]].{{Cite journal |last1=Blankenship |first1=Donald D. |last2=Moussessian |first2=Alina |last3=Chapin |first3=Elaine |last4=Young |first4=Duncan A. |last5=Patterson |first5=G. |last6=Plaut |first6=Jeffrey J. |last7=Freedman |first7=Adam P. |last8=Schroeder |first8=Dustin M. |last9=Grima |first9=Cyril |last10=Steinbrügge |first10=Gregor |last11=Soderlund |first11=Krista M. |last12=Ray |first12=Trina |last13=Richter |first13=Thomas G. |last14=Jones-Wilson |first14=Laura |last15=Wolfenbarger |first15=Natalie S. |date=June 2024 |title=Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-Surface (REASON) |journal=[[Space Science Reviews]] |language=en |volume=220 |issue=5 |pages=51 |doi=10.1007/s11214-024-01072-3 |issn=1572-9672 |pmc=11211191 |pmid=38948073|bibcode=2024SSRv..220...51B }} This instrument was built by Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ==== Europa Clipper Magnetometer (ECM) ==== The [[Europa Clipper Magnetometer]] (ECM) will be used to analyze the magnetic field around Europa. The instrument consists of three [[Current sensing#Fluxgate sensors|flux gates]] placed along an 8.5m (25ft) boom, which were stowed during launch and deployed afterwards.{{Cite web |title=ECM Instruments – NASA's Europa Clipper |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/ |access-date=October 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA |archive-date=October 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221004131828/https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/ |url-status=live }} The magnetic field of Jupiter is thought to induce electric current in a salty ocean beneath Europa’s ice, which in turn leads Europa to produce its own magnetic field, therefore by studying the strength and orientation of Europa's magnetic field over multiple flybys, scientists hope to be able to confirm the existence of Europa's subsurface ocean, as well as characterize the thickness of its icy crust and estimate the water's depth and salinity.{{Cite web |title=ECM: How We'll Use It |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/#otp_how_we'll_use_it |access-date=October 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA |archive-date=October 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221004131828/https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/#otp_how_we'll_use_it |url-status=live }} The instrument team leader is [[Margaret Kivelson]], [[University of Michigan]].{{cite journal |last1=Kivelson |first1=Margaret G. |last2=Jia |first2=Xianzhe |last3=Lee |first3=Karen A. |last4=Raymond |first4=Carol A. |last5=Khurana |first5=Krishan K. |last6=Perley |first6=Mitchell O. |last7=Biersteker |first7=John B. |last8=Blacksberg |first8=Jordana |last9=Caron |first9=Ryan |last10=Cochrane |first10=Corey J. |last11=Dawson |first11=Olivia R. |last12=Harris |first12=Camilla D. |access-date=March 13, 2019 |publisher=NASA}} {{Source-attribution}} ==== Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS) ==== [[File:Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS).tif|thumb|Two of the [[Faraday cup]] sensors for the [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding]] (PIMS) instrument. Left is the final flight configuration and right is at an earlier testing stage.]] The Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS) measures the [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] surrounding Europa to characterize the magnetic fields generated by plasma currents. These plasma currents mask the [[Electromagnetic induction|magnetic induction]] response of Europa's subsurface ocean. In conjunction with a magnetometer, it is key to determining Europa's ice shell thickness, ocean depth, and salinity. PIMS will also probe the mechanisms responsible for weathering and releasing material from Europa's surface into the [[atmosphere]] and [[ionosphere]] and understanding how Europa influences its local space environment and Jupiter's [[magnetosphere]].{{Cite conference |last1=Westlake |first1=Joseph |last2=Rymer |first2=A. 2016}} The principal investigator is Joseph Westlake of the Applied Physics Laboratory. ==== Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration (MASPEX) ==== The [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration]] (MASPEX) will determine the composition of the surface and subsurface ocean by measuring Europa's extremely tenuous atmosphere and any surface materials ejected into space.{{Cite web |title=Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration / Europa (MASPEX) |url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210519011818/https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08 |archive-date=May 19, 2021 |access-date=May 18, 2021 |website=[[NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive]] |publisher=NASA}}{{Cite web |last1=Waite |first1=Jack |last2=Lewis |first2=W. |last3=Kasprzak |first3=W. |last4=Anicich |first4=V. |last5=Block |first5=B. |last6=Cravens |first6=T. |last7=Fletcher |first7=G. |last8=Ip |first8=W. |last9=Luhmann |first9=J |date=August 13, 1998 |title=THE CASSINI ION AND NEUTRAL MASS SPECTROMETER (INMS) INVESTIGATION |url=https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211228164227/https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf |archive-date=December 28, 2021 |access-date=May 18, 2021 |website=[[Lunar and Planetary Laboratory]] |publisher=[[University of Arizona]]}} Jack Waite, who led development of MASPEX, was also Science Team Lead of the [[Cassini–Huygens|Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer]] (INMS) on the Cassini spacecraft. The principal investigator is Jim Burch of [[Southwest Research Institute]], who was previously the leader of the [[Magnetospheric Multiscale Mission]]. ==== Surface Dust Analyzer (SUDA) ==== [[File:Europa Clipper's Dust Analyzer sensor head.jpg|thumb|Europa Clipper's Dust Analyzer sensor head]] The [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUrface Dust Analyzer]] (SUDA) is a [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] that will measure the composition of small solid particles ejected from Europa, providing the opportunity to directly sample the surface and potential plumes on low-altitude flybys. The instrument is capable of identifying traces of organic and inorganic compounds in the ice of [[ejecta]],{{Cite journal |last=Kempf |first=Sascha |display-authors=etal |date=May 2012 |title=Linear high resolution dust mass spectrometer for a mission to the Galilean satellites |journal=Planetary and Space Science |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=10–20 |bibcode=2012P&SS...65...10K |doi=10.1016/j.pss.2011.12.019}} and is sensitive enough to detect signatures of life even if the sample contains less than a single bacterial cell in a collected ice grain.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/sciadv.adl0849 |title=How to identify cell material in a single ice grain emitted from Enceladus or Europa |year=2024 |last1=Klenner |first1=Fabian |last2=Bönigk |first2=Janine |last3=Napoleoni |first3=Maryse |last4=Hillier |first4=Jon |last5=Khawaja |first5=Nozair |last6=Olsson-Francis |first6=Karen |last7=Cable |first7=Morgan L. |last8=Malaska |first8=Michael J. |last9=Kempf |first9=Sascha |last10=Abel |first10=Bernd |last11=Postberg |first11=Frank |journal=Science Advances |volume=10 |issue=12 |pages=eadl0849 |pmid=38517965 |pmc=10959401 |bibcode=2024SciA...10L.849K }} The principal investigator is Sascha Kempf of the [[University of Colorado Boulder]]. ==== Gravity & Radio Science ==== Although it was designed primarily for communications, the high-gain radio antenna will be used to perform additional radio observations and investigate Europa's gravitational field, acting as a [[radio science subsystem]]. Measuring the [[Doppler shift]] in the radio signals between the spacecraft and Earth will allow the spacecraft's motion to be determined in detail. As the spacecraft performs each of its 45 Europa flybys, its trajectory will be altered by the moon's gravitational field. The Doppler data will be used to determine the higher order coefficients of that gravity field, to determine the moon's interior structure, and to examine how Europa is deformed by [[tidal forces]].{{cite journal |last1=Mazarico |first1=Erwan |last2=Buccino |first2=Dustin |last3=Castillo-Rogez |first3=Julie |last4=Dombard |first4=Andrew J. |last5=Genova |first5=Antonio |last6=Hussmann |first6=Hauke |last7=Kiefer |first7=Walter S. |last8=Lunine |first8=Jonathan I. |last9=McKinnon |first9=William B. |last10=Nimmo |first10=Francis |last11=Park |first11=Ryan S. |last12=Roberts |first12=James H. |last13=Srinivasan |first13=Dipak K. |last14=Steinbrügge |first14=Gregor |last15=Tortora |first15=Paolo |last16=Withers |first16=Paul |title=The Europa Clipper Gravity and Radio Science Investigation |journal=Space Science Reviews |date=June 2023 |volume=219 |issue=4 |page=30 |doi=10.1007/s11214-023-00972-0 |bibcode=2023SSRv..219...30M |display-authors=1|doi-access=free }} The instrument team leader is Erwan Mazarico of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.{{Cite web |title=Gravity/Radio Science Instruments |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/gravity-radio-science/ |access-date=November 12, 2022 |publisher=NASA |archive-date=November 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221112081205/https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/gravity-radio-science/ |url-status=live }} == Launch and trajectory == [[File:NASA's SpaceX Europa Clipper Launch (KSC-20241014-PH-AJN01 0022) (cropped).jpg|thumb|[[Falcon Heavy]] lifts off with Europa Clipper from [[Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39A]] on Monday, Oct. 14, 2024; 12:06 pm. EDT ]] [[File:NASA's Europa Clipper Mission- Spacecraft Separation.webm|thumb|Europa Clipper separates from Falcon Heavy's Second Stage after deployment]] Congress had originally mandated that Europa Clipper be launched on NASA's [[Space Launch System]] (SLS) [[super heavy-lift launch vehicle]], but NASA had requested that other vehicles be allowed to launch the spacecraft due to a foreseen lack of available SLS vehicles.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 10, 2020 |title=Cost growth prompts changes to Europa Clipper instruments |url=https://spacenews.com/cost-growth-prompts-changes-to-europa-clipper-instruments/ |access-date=July 10, 2020 |publisher=SpaceNews |archive-date=September 29, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929074855/https://spacenews.com/cost-growth-prompts-changes-to-europa-clipper-instruments/ |url-status=live }} The United States Congress's 2021 omnibus spending bill directed the NASA Administrator to conduct a full and open competition to select a commercial launch vehicle if the conditions to launch the probe on a SLS rocket cannot be met.{{Cite news |last=Howell |first=Elizabeth |date=December 22, 2020 |title=NASA receives US$23.3 billion for 2021 fiscal year in Congress' omnibus spending bill |publisher=SPACE.com |url=https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill |url-status=live |access-date=December 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116062645/https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill |archive-date=January 16, 2021}} On January 25, 2021, NASA's Planetary Missions Program Office formally directed the mission team to "immediately cease efforts to maintain SLS compatibility" and move forward with a commercial launch vehicle. On February 10, 2021, it was announced that the mission would use a 5.5-year trajectory to the Jovian system, with gravity-assist maneuvers involving Mars (March 1, 2025) and Earth (December 3, 2026). Launch was targeted for a 21-day period between October 10 and 30, 2024, giving an arrival date in April 2030, and backup launch dates were identified in 2025 and 2026. The SLS option would have entailed a direct trajectory to Jupiter taking less than three years. One alternative to the direct trajectory was identified as using a commercial rocket, with a longer 6-year cruise time involving gravity assist maneuvers at [[Venus]], Earth and/or [[Mars]]. Additionally, a launch on a [[Delta IV Heavy]] with a gravity assist at Venus was considered.{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |author-link=Eric Berger (meteorologist) |date=July 23, 2021 |title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |publisher=[[Ars Technica]]}} In July 2021 the decision was announced to launch on a Falcon Heavy rocket, in fully expendable configuration. Three reasons were given: reasonable launch cost (ca. $178 million), questionable SLS availability, and possible damage to the payload due to strong vibrations caused by the solid boosters attached to the SLS launcher. The move to Falcon Heavy saved an estimated US$2 billion in launch costs alone.{{Cite web |last=Ralph |first=Eric |title=SpaceX Falcon Heavy to launch NASA ocean moon explorer, saving the US billions |url=https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211128000524/https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |archive-date=November 28, 2021 |access-date=November 28, 2021 |website=Teslarati|date=July 25, 2021 }}{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=July 23, 2021 |title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |access-date=November 28, 2021 |website=arstechnica}} NASA was not sure an SLS would be available for the mission since the [[Artemis program]] would use SLS rockets extensively, and the SLS's use of [[solid rocket booster]]s (SRBs) generates more vibrations in the payload than a launcher that does not use SRBs. The cost to redesign Europa Clipper for the SLS vibratory environment was estimated at US$1 billion. Europa Clipper was launched on October 14, 2024, at 12:06 p.m. EDT from [[Launch Pad 39A]] at NASA's [[Kennedy Space Center]] in Florida.{{Cite web |title=SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket launches NASA's Europa Clipper probe to explore icy Jupiter ocean moon |website=[[Space.com]] |date=October 14, 2024 |url=https://www.space.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-europa-clipper-launch}} [[Hurricane Milton]] caused a launch attempt for October 10 to be scrubbed,{{Cite web |last=Harwood |first=William |date=October 6, 2024 |title=FAA clears European asteroid probe for launch, but stormy weather threatens delay |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/faa-clears-european-asteroid-probe-launch-stormy-weather-threatens-delay/ |access-date=October 7, 2024 |publisher=CBS News |language=en-US}} resulting in the launch being finalized for October 14. {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | width = 300px | header = Animation of Europa Clipper | image1 = Animation of Europa Clipper trajectory.gif | caption1 = Around the Sun
{{Legend inline|Magenta|Europa Clipper}}{{·}}{{Legend inline| RoyalBlue| Earth}}{{·}}{{Legend inline| Lime| Jupiter}}{{·}}{{Legend inline|Yellow|Sun}}{{·}}{{Legend inline|Darkkhaki|Mars}} | image2 = Animation of Europa Clipper trajectory around Jupiter.gif | caption2 = Around Jupiter
{{Legend inline|Magenta|Europa Clipper}}{{·}}{{Legend inline|Cyan|Europa}}{{·}}{{Legend inline|Gold|Callisto}}{{·}}{{Legend inline|OrangeRed|Io}} | footer = }} The trajectory of Europa Clipper will include a gravity assist from Mars on March 1, 2025, allowing it to speed further away from the Sun, then down towards the Sun and back out, and gain additional kinetic energy from an Earth gravity assist on December 3, 2026. The probe will then arc (reach [[aphelion]]) beyond Jupiter's orbit on October 4, 2029{{cite web |title=Eyes on the Solar System: October 4, 2029 | website=NASA|date=November 7, 2024 | url=https://eyes.nasa.gov/apps/solar-system/#/sc_europa_clipper/distance?rate=0&time=2029-10-04T12:00:00.000+00:00&to=jupiter | access-date=November 7, 2024}} See also the point at which deldot equals 0 for Clipper relative to the Sun in the [https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons/ Horizons system app]. before slowly falling into Jupiter's [[gravity well]] and executing its orbital insertion burn in April 2030.{{cite AV media |people=Manley, Scott|title=SpaceX Ditched an Entire Falcon Heavy To Launch NASA's Massive Probe To Europa! | website=YouTube|publisher=Scott Manley |time=3 minutes 40 seconds|format=YouTube video |date=October 21, 2024 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QYieX09IgXw&t=220 | access-date=October 25, 2024}} {{As of|2014}}, the trajectory in the Jupiter system is planned as follows.{{update inline|date=October 2024}} After entry into the Jupiter system, Europa Clipper will perform a flyby of Ganymede at an altitude of {{Convert abbreviated|500|km|mi}}, which will reduce the spacecraft velocity by ~{{Convert abbreviated|400|m/s|mph}}. This will be followed by firing the main engine at a distance of 11 Rj (Jovian radii), to provide a further ~{{Convert abbreviated|840|m/s|mph}} of [[delta-V]], sufficient to insert the spacecraft into a 202-day orbit around Jupiter. Once the spacecraft reaches the [[apoapsis]] of that initial orbit, it will perform another engine burn to provide a ~{{Convert abbreviated|122|m/s|mph}} [[periapsis]] raise maneuver (PRM).{{citation |last1=Buffington |first1=Brent |title=Trajectory Design for the Europa Clipper Mission Concept |date=August 5, 2014 |url=https://www.trylam.com/CPP/AIAA_SPACE2014_Buffington_PrePrint_v2.pdf |access-date=May 11, 2024 |language=en |archive-date=May 1, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240501185746/https://www.trylam.com/CPP/AIAA_SPACE2014_Buffington_PrePrint_v2.pdf |url-status=live }}{{update inline|date=October 2024}} The spacecraft's cruise and science phases will overlap with the [[European Space Agency|ESA]]'s JUICE spacecraft, which was launched in April 2023 and will arrive at Jupiter in July 2031. Europa Clipper is due to arrive at Jupiter 15 months prior to JUICE, despite a launch date planned 18 months later, owing to a more powerful launch vehicle and a faster flight plan with fewer gravity assists. == Public outreach == To raise public awareness of the Europa Clipper mission, NASA undertook a "Message In A Bottle" campaign, i.e. an actual "Send Your Name to Europa" campaign on June 1, 2023, through which people around the world were invited to send their names as signatories to a poem called "In Praise of Mystery: A Poem for Europa" written by the U.S. Poet Laureate [[Ada Limón]], for the 2.9-billion-kilometer (1.8-billion mi) voyage to Jupiter. The poem describes the connections between Earth and Europa.{{Cite web |title=NASA's Message in a Bottle |url=https://go.nasa.gov/455Yt0L |access-date=June 1, 2023 |website=NASA's Europa Clipper |language=en |archive-date=June 16, 2023 |archive-url=https://europa.nasa.gov/message-in-a-bottle/learn/|url-status=live }} The poem is engraved on Europa Clipper inside a [[tantalum]] metal plate, about 7 by 11 inches (18 by 28 centimeters), that seals an opening into the vault. The inward-facing side of the metal plate is engraved with the poem in the poet's own handwriting. The public participants' names are etched onto a microchip attached to the plate, within an artwork of a wine bottle surrounded by the four [[Galilean moons]]. After registering their names, participants received a digital ticket with details of the mission's launch and destination. According to NASA, 2,620,861 people signed their names to Europa Clipper's Message in a Bottle, most of whom were from the United States.{{Cite web |title=NASA's Message in a Bottle |url=https://go.nasa.gov/455Yt0L |access-date=March 24, 2024 |website=NASA's Europa Clipper |language=en |archive-date=June 16, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240616100628/https://europa.nasa.gov/message-in-a-bottle/join-us/?utm_source=message_in_a_bottle_share&utm_medium=organic&utm_campaign=message_in_a_bottle&utm_content=europa_clipper |url-status=live }} Other elements etched on the inwards side together with the poem and names are the [[Drake equation]], representations of the [[spectral line]]s of a [[hydrogen atom]] and the [[hydroxyl radical]], together known as the [[Water hole (radio)|water hole]], and a portrait of planetary scientist [[Ron Greeley]].{{cite web |title=NASA Unveils Design for Message Heading to Jupiter's Moon Europa |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/nasa-unveils-design-for-message-heading-to-jupiters-moon-europa |website=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) |access-date=March 11, 2024 |archive-date=March 9, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240309115210/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/nasa-unveils-design-for-message-heading-to-jupiters-moon-europa |url-status=live }} {{Source-attribution}} The outward-facing panel features art that highlights Earth's connection to Europa. Linguists collected recordings of the word "water" spoken in 103 languages, from families of languages around the world. The audio files were converted into waveforms and etched into the plate. The waveforms radiate out from a symbol representing the [[American Sign Language]] sign for "water".{{Cite web|url=https://astrobiology.com/2024/03/an-astrobiology-droid-asks-and-answers-how-many-ways-can-you-say-water.html|title=An Astrobiology Droid Asks And Answers 'How Many Ways Can You Say Water'?|first=Keith|last=Cowing|date=March 9, 2024|website=Astrobiology|access-date=March 11, 2024|archive-date=June 16,
